thought.author: Konrad Zuse
description: Happy Monday ðŸ‘‹, today's issue of #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Konrad Zuse, the inventor of the first programmable computer "Z3", who would have turned 110 today on this very 22nd of June.

His quote dates back from a time when artificial intelligence was any more than just an idea. Interestingly, we are challenging the same questions today, as artificial intelligence, machine learning and the good old fashioned robots are a reality.
thought.quote: The danger of computers becoming like humans is not as great as the danger of humans becoming like computers.

thought.author: Harold Abelson
description: Following up on yesterday's issue of #ThoughtsOfProgramming and the idea of producing clean, comprehensive and maintainable code to increase team effectiveness, here's another very valid point by Harold Abelson.
thought.quote: Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute.

thought.author: Larry Tesler
description: How would modern user interfaces look like without copy & paste? Today's issue of #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Larry Tesler, who invented the cut, copy and paste commands during his time at Xerox PARC.
thought.quote: You cannot reduce the complexity of a given task beyond a certain point. Once you've reached that point, you can only shift the burden around.
